soc.server

Class SOCGameMessageHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.server.SOCGameMessageHandler
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    GameMessageHandler

    public class SOCGameMessageHandler
extends java.lang.Object
implements GameMessageHandler
    Game message handler for SOCGameHandler: Dispatches all messages received from the InboundMessageQueue related to specific games (implementing SOCMessageForGame). All other messages are handled by SOCServerMessageHandler instead.

    Message Flow:

    • Inbound game messages arrive here from SOCServerMessageDispatcher.dispatch(SOCMessage, Connection).
    • Each specific message class is identified in dispatch(..) which calls handler methods such as handleBANKTRADE(SOCGame, Connection, SOCBankTrade). See dispatch(..) method's javadoc for more details on per-message handling.
    • Most handler methods call into SOCGameHandler for the game's "business logic" abstracted from inbound message processing, and then SOCServer to send result messages to all players and observers in the game.
    Before v2.0.00 this class was SOCServer.processCommand(String, Connection) and related handler methods, all part of SOCServer. So, some may have @since javadoc labels with versions older than 2.0.00. Refactoring for 2.0.00 in 2013 moved the handler methods from SOCServer to SOCGameHandler, and in 2016 to this class.
    Since:
    2.0.00
    Author:
    Alessandro D'Ottavio
    See Also:
    SOCServerMessageHandler

    • Method Detail

      • dispatch

        public boolean dispatch(SOCGame game,
                        SOCMessageForGame message,
                        Connection connection)
        Dispatch any request or event coming from a client player for a specific game. This method is called from SOCServerMessageDispatcher.dispatch(SOCMessage, Connection) when the message is recognized as a game-related request, command, or event.

        Some game messages (such as player sits down, or board reset voting) are handled the same for all game types. These are handled by SOCServerMessageHandler; they should be ignored here and not appear in the switch statement.

        Caller of this method will catch any thrown Exceptions.

        Specified by:
        dispatch in interface GameMessageHandler
        Parameters:
        game - Game in which client connection is sending message. Never null; from SOCMessageForGame.getGameName().
        message - Message from client connection. Never null.
        connection - Connection to the Client sending message. Never null. Connection.getData() won't be null unless message implements SOCMessageFromUnauthClient.
        Returns:
        true if processed, false if ignored or unknown message type
